msgSnippet: A.P. There is a lot of documentation and plenty of examples hanging around that would give you a place to start.  Look at JUnit s tests for instance.  Look at

From: "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

A.P.

There is a lot of documentation and plenty of examples hanging around that
would give you a place to start.  Look at JUnit's tests for instance.  Look
at the sample Money tests that are published with JUnit.  Go to junit.org,
or the junit wiki, or the SourceForge site, etc.  I think it would be a good
idea for you to try learning what you can from the documentation and
examples that already exist, then, when you have more specific questions,
ask the group.

It isn't that we are unwilling to answer questions, it's just that I think
most people expect that new comers will put forth some effort in addressing
the learning curve.  Personaly, I don't expect you to make yourself
completely versed in JUnit, I simply expect you to familiarize yourself with
the product enough to be able to ask intelligent questions about it.

Try to understand what an Assert is, what a TestCase is, what a TestResult
is, what a TestRunner is...  These are the basics.  (Actually, you could
even skip TestResult for now.)  Then, if you have a class that you already
know you want to write tests for (or you are doing test first design and
have an idea of the class you will be writing) tell us about it.  We will
then have a common language for describing how to write the tests -- JUnit's
framework!

I hope you don't take this email offensively.  I understand that it is
sometimes overwhelming to learn a new product (JUnit), not to mention a new
paradigm (unit testing or testing in general).  I only hope to guide you to
some possible good starting places.

-Jason

    > > developers to tester or do we have any templates / design guides
    > > ? Thanks, Pankaj Solanki
